title: title

text: Some neuropeople asked me why we were only plotting the right hemisphere in nilearn. In fact, in our plotting functions, in the sagittal view, the brain is "looking to" the right, which means that this is a right hemisphere to neuropeople. We probably want to flip it when the slice is in the left part of the brain in plotting and make two sagittal plots (one left hemisphere and one right hemisphere) in the glass brain.
title: Hemisphere plotting

text:
> Indeed, we need to do 'import nilearn as ni'

I pushed this change in commit 01b479b.

> You need a test that fails before this commit and works after, that way we are convinced that it works.

+1
I pushed 3115ba7 which contains a tests covering more use cases related to globbing. I'm waiting for the tests to fail and will push the fix later.
Ok, so tests are now completely failing... (but not for the initial reason). @GaelVaroquaux maybe you prefer to validate the tests first or is it ok if I push my solution now ?
@lesteve @KamalakerDadi your recent comments have been adressed ;)
@KamalakerDadi, @GaelVaroquaux @lesteve @AlexandreAbraham, is this ok to merge ?

> Maybe an additional test for the edge case where a real glob (i.e. containing *, [, or ?) matches only one file?

It's already there I think : see line 235 in test_niimg_conversions.py
Thanks for your comment @lesteve : I pushed 2 commits that should address those use cases.
Thanks, this will make my day !
Looks rather good, but documentation should be added to illustrate the behavior.

First of all, there is a problem that `nilearn.EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS` and `nilearn._utils.niimg_conversions.EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS` are two different variables, so setting one has no effect on the other. As an illustration:

``` python
from nilearn._utils import niimg_conversions
niimg_conversions.check_niimg('this_file_does_not_exist')  # error with please set global constants EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS to False

import nilearn
nilearn.EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS = False
niimg_conversions.check_niimg('this_file_does_not_exist')  # still the same error as previously
```

Also I am a bit confused about EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS functionality. Why don't we want to always use `EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS = True` ? 

Is it because we worry about files which contains the following characters: `*`, `[` or `?` ?

> First of all, there is a problem that nilearn.EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS and
> nilearn._utils.niimg_conversions.EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS

Indeed, we need to do 'import nilearn as ni' in
nilearn._utils.niimg_conversions and then access EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS as
"ni.EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS"

> I pushed this change in commit 01b479b.

You need a test that fails before this commit and works after, that way
we are convinced that it works.

> Indeed, we need to do 'import nilearn as ni' in nilearn._utils.niimg_conversions and then access EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS as "ni.EXPAND_PATH_WILDCARDS"

Note that I couldn't figure out a way to do the same thing with a relative import. Not sure how likely this is to create a problem in the real world.

> You need a test that fails before this commit and works after, that way we are convinced that it works.

:+1:

> Note that I couldn't figure out a way to do the same thing with a relative
> import.

Good point.

> Not sure how likely this is to create a problem in the real world.

Let's not loose sleep on this and move on.

> ```
> I pushed 3115ba7 which contains a tests covering more use cases related to
> globbing. I'm waiting for the tests to fail and will push the fix later.
> ```

Test driven development! Yey
Apart from some usability questions, :+1:
Maybe an additional test for the edge case where a real glob (i.e. containing `*`, `[`, or `?`) matches only one file?

> It's already there I think : see line 235 in test_niimg_conversions.py

Good point I missed that. Looking at your tests a little bit more I think we should be testing 3d data too.

If you only have test.nii which is a 3d image in the current working directory, you expect.

``` python
 # 3d image
check_niimg('test.nii')
 # 4d image with last dimension 1 i.e. it is equivalent to check_niimg(['test.nii'])
check_niimg('test*.nii')
```

Merging this one, thanks!

Still a few regexp rather than glob remaining but I'll fix them up in master directly.

'match'
return_iterator

text: SHould we expand it? It would be more convenient for me but I don't know if it's YAGNI or not.
title: Have the niimgs checking function optionally convert globbing
Have the niimgs checking function optionally convert globbing

text:
> To sum up the work to be done:
> - Have check_niimg optionally use glob (and sort if using glob) (with the default being true)
> - Have a constant at the level of nilearn.init to control this behavior
> - Have a very clear error message if a glob returns an empty list, that explains what is going on, and > assumes that the user might have made a glob by mistake (thus points out the above constant).

@GaelVaroquaux, I pushed 419019a that should address this feature. A test is missing though.

I think it's YAGNI, and we'll bring us more trouble than the anticipated good it might do for users. Let them expand their paths themselves. Also, `nilearn.plotting` is not supposed to be a unix shell environment ;)

To sum up the work to be done:
- Have check_niimg optionally use glob (and sort if using glob) (with the default being true)
- Have a constant at the level of `nilearn.__init__` to control this behavior
- Have a very clear error message if a glob returns an empty list, that explains what is going on, and assumes that the user might have made a glob by mistake (thus points out the above constant).
Maybe this behavior should be restricted to `check_niimg_4d`?

> Maybe this behavior should be restricted to check_niimg_4d?

Well, if we want to expand '~' we can do it in check_niimg. But for the
rest, I agree.
I agree with Gael that glob-integration could increase comfort of nilearn users. After all, we do glob.glob before loading anyways.
@aabadie  It would be nice if you do PR tagged as **[WIP]** and ping somebody if you need help.

> @aabadie It would be nice if you do PR tagged as [WIP] and ping somebody if you need help.

:+1: in general commenting on commits is not a really good idea, because comments tend to be completely lost if there is a rebase. It is a lot better to start a PR so that the discussion happens all in one place.

title: title

text:
I am looking for some python solutions to plot neuroimaging data from mice and rats.

I was pleased (and surprised) to see that nilearn offers some apparently quite nice plotting functions (at least for human data). I am wondering:
- Why does it make sense to package these plotting functions together with functions better described by ni_learn_? Would it not be more intuitive (and perhaps make the plotting function modules more readily recognisable as such)  to package them as "niplot" or something of the sort?
- Is there any (more-or-less) easy way to plot some rodent data with the functions currently offered by nilearn?
title: Small Rodent Neuroimaging plots in Python
Small Rodent Neuroimaging plots in Python

text:
> what about the glass brain? Is drawing a set of contours myself the best
> way to go about it? any advice on how to do that?

Glass Brain was made by hand. Take a look at

nilearn/nilearn/plotting/glass_brain_files/*.svg

You will see that there are three vector drawings. If you can create these
for the main gyri/sulci of the mouse brain, you can have a mouse glass
brain.

So it depends on how much effort you want to put into it.

Michael

On Mon, Oct 19, 2015 at 1:49 PM, Gael Varoquaux notifications@github.com
wrote:

> The glass brain is going to be specific to realigned humain brain.
> 
> Sorry, there is no ways outlines can be automatized.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/issues/797#issuecomment-149192237.

On Mon, Oct 19, 2015 at 2:20 PM, Horea Christian notifications@github.com
wrote:

> So if I want a rodent glass brain, "all" I have to do is take one outer
> and one inner structural slice for each axis, import it into inkscape, draw
> some contours on top of it, delete the imported bitmap objects, and save
> teh documents? Is there anything I am missing about this which would make
> it particularly non-trivial?
> 
> Yes, you choose a slice of your normalized rodent brain (if this exists)
> and use inkscape to draw the contours of relevance. For your purposes you
> may just replace the human glass brain with yours. Otherwise the code needs
> to be changed to allow different options.
> 
> What would the advantage of a PNG over a SVG be here? why would aligning
> to a PNG be more difficult than aligning to a SVG?
> 
> I don't see a difference. It would just be to support more background
> images. There is no realignment: The image is considered to be in MNI space
> for human brains. It is then resampled if necessary to the right resolution
> and plotted.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/issues/797#issuecomment-149198662.

> Would it not be more intuitive (and perhaps make the plotting function modules more readily recognisable as such) to package them as "niplot" or something of the sort?

This has been discussed and the code is not mature enough to be separated from the core.

> Is there any (more-or-less) easy way to plot some rodent data with the functions currently offered by nilearn?

You can customize the background image used for regular plotting functions. For `plot_glass_brain`, the background template can be customized but it is not trivial for the moment.

What do you need exactly ?

Something like this would be really nice:

![mouse_fMRI](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/950524/10575113/abbf6ee6-765a-11e5-8c42-63c338b6c70a.jpg)
If you have a mouse anatomy and statistical maps as nifti files, you can use plot_stats_maps to do what you want.
what about the glass brain? Is drawing a set of contours myself the best way to go about it? any advice on how to do that?

The glass brain is going to be specific to realigned humain brain.

Sorry, there is no ways outlines can be automatized.
I have met people that would like to substitute the SVG file by freesurfer images. Maybe we should allow that.

> I have met people that would like to substitute the SVG file by freesurfer
> images. Maybe we should allow that.

With what king of input format?
Replacing it with a PNG should be fairly easy. The user just has to be sure that the image is aligned with the original SVG (which is difficult in the case of a rodent... I agree).

I am here partly because I want to get away from freesurfer - which almost all modern plotting functionalities seem to depend on. For what it's worth I would recommend against depending on it, freesurfer itself depends on very outdated versions of minc, and upstream is very non-responsive - even by scientific software standards...

In theory, I would be +1 for input of background as a PNG.

However, I worry a lot about people not realigning their backgrounds
well, and publishing plots that are incorrect.

Also, I am afraid that this feature is going to generate a lot of user
support problems (my brain is not well aligned, please help).

I am a bit unsure whether it is wise to open this pandora box.

> However, I worry a lot about people not realigning their backgrounds well, and publishing plots that are incorrect. 

This is already the case with the current background: we have no guarantee that the data provided is aligned with it.

Maybe we can give a choice at least between the SVG and a 3D image?

So if I want a rodent glass brain, "all" I have to do is take one outer and one inner structural  slice for each axis, import it into inkscape, draw some contours on top of it, delete the imported bitmap objects, and save the documents? Is there anything I am missing about this which would make it particularly non-trivial?

What would the advantage of a PNG over a SVG be here? why would aligning to a PNG be more difficult than aligning to a SVG?

> Maybe we can give a choice at least between the SVG and a 3D image?

Maybe just a 3D mask image and we compute the online of it (easy, just
compute the max along the direction and do a contour in matplotlib?

This would be open for contributions, but I don't see my team investing
in it in the short term, though, given how overcommitted we are.

> Ping @aabadie, apparently I stole your job. But I've done the easy part, the hardest part is to set it cleverly when needed :P.

No problem @AlexandreAbraham, your change is a nice contribution.
@AlexandreAbraham,  in case you missed it, the test is failing on circle ci. Probably an issue when setting memory limit on the VM.

> The problem seems that the code segfaults instead of raising a memory error... Maybe I asked for too much memory?

This is a possibility but I would be surprised as the maximum memory is set to 10000000 (10MB) and the size of the array is 12MB which is not that much.

Maybe using a strategy based on MemoryProfiler would help.

> FWIW @aabadie has a solution for this use case (testing nilearn memory consumption as per #736) based on memory_profiler

 @AlexandreAbraham, @lesteve, if you agree, I'll propose a PR based on that solution.
The problem seems that the code segfaults instead of raising a memory error... Maybe I asked for too much memory?

> The problem seems that the code segfaults instead of raising a memory error...
> Maybe I asked for too much memory?

Indeed, under old versions of Python, there were segfaults when you asked
for too much memory.

FWIW @aabadie has a solution for this use case (testing nilearn memory consumption as per #736) based on memory_profiler, which is part of https://github.com/joblib/joblib/pull/260.

I am not entirely sure it is worth investigating more time making this PR work.

> @AlexandreAbraham, @lesteve, if you agree, I'll propose a PR based on that solution.

This is fine with me. It would be great to find a few tests to add in order to test functions in nilearn where  memory consumption actually matters. @AlexandreAbraham, @GaelVaroquaux any suggestions ?

> Indeed, under old versions of Python, there were segfaults when you asked
> for too much memory.

But we don't use older versions of Python. This is why this seems strange to me.

> FWIW @aabadie has a solution for this use case (testing nilearn memory consumption as per #736) based on memory_profiler, which is part of joblib/joblib#260.

Yes, I know how to do it with `memory_profiler`. The goal of this PR was to rely on the system and avoid a dependency.

> @AlexandreAbraham, @lesteve, if you agree, I'll propose a PR based on that solution.

I won't say no :P 

>  It would be great to find a few tests to add in order to test functions in nilearn where memory consumption actually matters. @AlexandreAbraham, @GaelVaroquaux any suggestions ?

Any function that is supposed to treat data iteratively such as `compute_multi_epi_mask` (or `multi_compute_epi_mask` or `compute_epi_multi_mask`).
Handing it over to @aabadie !

> @aabadie, setting the limit of memory is protected. The error seems to be that a segfault is triggered when I allocate too much memory instead of a memory error. I'll try to put a smaller object in the test.

You put a smaller object but didn't change the memory_limit. I would guess that's why the Travis tests are now failing.

> I don't get your comment. The error should be triggered when the allocated object size is higher than the limit, which is the case. Or maybe I have my memory usage estimation wrong?

I haven't double-checked the memory usage computation but it looks like the Travis failure is due to the fact that the memory usage doesn't go over the memory_limit threshold.

On top of that it looks like it only fails for a few distributions but not for the other, weird.

text:
currently plot_stat_map will crash if a scalar is passed to cut_coords in single-axis display mode:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mk_tsne_figure.py", line 57, in <module>
    draw_cross=False,display_mode='z',colorbar=False,cut_coords=0.)
  File "/Users/poldrack/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn-0.1.5.dev0-py2.7.egg/nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py", line 891, in plot_stat_map
    **kwargs)
  File "/Users/poldrack/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn-0.1.5.dev0-py2.7.egg/nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py", line 163, in _plot_img_with_bg
    colorbar=colorbar)
  File "/Users/poldrack/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn-0.1.5.dev0-py2.7.egg/nilearn/plotting/displays.py", line 400, in init_with_figure
    cut_coords = cls.find_cut_coords(img, threshold, cut_coords)
  File "/Users/poldrack/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn-0.1.5.dev0-py2.7.egg/nilearn/plotting/displays.py", line 950, in find_cut_coords
    n_cuts=cut_coords)
  File "/Users/poldrack/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn-0.1.5.dev0-py2.7.egg/nilearn/plotting/find_cuts.py", line 213, in find_cut_slices
    spacing = max(int(.5 / n_cuts * data.shape[axis]), 1)
ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero
```

should check to see if the arguments to cut_coords are a list, and coerce single coord into a list if passed as a scalar.
title: check for proper coords on plot_stat_map
check for proper coords on plot_stat_map

text:
Russ,

cut_coords : None, a tuple of floats, or an integer
            The MNI coordinates of the point where the cut is performed
            If display_mode is 'ortho', this should be a 3-tuple: (x, y, z)
            For display_mode == 'x', 'y', or 'z', then these are the
            coordinates of each cut in the corresponding direction.
            If None is given, the cuts is calculated automaticaly.
            If display_mode is 'x', 'y' or 'z', cut_coords can be an integer,
            in which case it specifies the number of cuts to perform

If _cut_coords_ is a scalar (as in your example), then it's expected to be
and integer representing the number of cuts you want. We can't do the
coercing automatically, as this would run into conflicts with the rest of
the logic. The error you're getting is because the 0 you passed for
_cut_coords_ is being interpreted as number of slices (_n_cuts_ in your
traceback), leading to a zero-division. The latter tells us there is a
stealth bug in the _find_cuts_ function: it should sanitize the value
_n_cuts_ param and throw a meaningful error in case invalid (for example,
in case it's _0_).

thanks - yes, better error reporting sounds like a good solution.

text:
This is due to the use of non safe `get_data` in `copy_img`.

Typically this invalidate cache:

``` python

def f(img):
    print('Not cached')

mem = Memory(cache_dir='nilearn_cache')
img = NiftiImage(np.ones(10, 10, 10, 10), affine=np.ones(4))

mem.cache(f)(img)
mem.cache(f)(img)
img2 = copy_img(img)
mem.cache(f)(img)
```

Output:

```
Not cached
Not cached
```
title: copy_img has a side effect on image
copy_img has a side effect on image

text:
Good catch!

A PR to fix this would be great.
Fix is straightforward, I just need to write a test and I will push it

> Fix is straight forward,

It is indeed, because you understand the package :)
@arthurmensch : can you either do this today, or help Aina do it

Cc @ainafp : I think that this is something that you could work on.

The idea is to use nilearn._utils.niimg._safe_get_data instead of the get_data method.
Have you opened a PR? This is the easiest way to comment on your changes.

@GaelVaroquaux @arthurmensch :

I changed it but it still creates a new image because it uses new_img_like() from nilearn.image.image
I can substitute the whole line and return just _safe_get_data(img). 
Is this fine? In this case, instead of 
`new_img_like(img, img.get_data().copy(), img.get_affine().copy(),  copy_header=True)`
it just makes a deep copy
`img = copy.deepcopy(img)`
if it is not cached inside _safe_get_data. 

If you agree I change it. I wrote the test based on what Arthur did.

@GaelVaroquaux 
In new_img_like() in from nilearn.image.image, when copy_header is set to true, changing  header['scl_slope'], header['scl_inter'],  header['cal_max'] or header['cal_max'] change the value of the hash. 

```
img = Nifti1Image(np.ones((2, 2, 2, 2)), affine=np.eye(4))
joblib.hash(img)
img2 = new_img_like(img, np.ones((2, 2, 2, 2)), img.get_affine().copy(), copy_header=True)
joblib.hash(img)  
```
Nevermind. It was just a copy.copy of the header inside new_img_like(). I changed it to copy.deepcopy()
Done!

title: title

text:
In the docstring of nilearn, we should list the subpackage (aside from _utils) with a short description of what's in it. The goal is to make it easier to users to know where to look to find a functionality.

The docstring of scipy could be an inspiration.
title: The docstring of nilearn.__init__ should list subpackages
The docstring of nilearn.__init__ should list subpackages

text:
I took the docstring of scipy as an example for documentating the top level **__init__.py** file. As mentionned here (https://docs.python.org/3.4/tutorial/modules.html#importing-from-a-package), I also defined and filled the **__all__** attribute with the "public" submodules of nilearn.

We could also go further by writing the all docstring in all submodules.

> We could also go further by writing the all docstring in all submodules.

I think it's probably overkill for now.

A couple of tips:
- double underscore does emphasis (aka bold) in markdown so you want to use backquotes to escape them, see this [link](https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/) for more details.
- using Fix #number in a PR description does automatically close the issue #number once the PR is merged

text: In MultiPCA, dataset files are masked one after the other to save memory. This is done by repeated calls to `filter_and_mask`. An easier (and more pythonic) way to do that would be to provide a masking iterator that does this job on the fly.
title: Masking iterator in NiftiMasker

text: I'm going to close this one because I can't see a clean way to do it while being in parallel.

text:
The Python 3.5 now has the most recent versions. This uncovered a buglet in space_net.py for python 3 and numpy < 1.9 ... @dohmatob maybe you just want to glance a the fix?

The root issue is that:

``` python
import numpy as np

array = np.arange(10)
array[range(3)]
```

doesn't work in numpy < 1.9 (array index can not be an iterator). It does the right thing in numpy >= 1.9.
title: [MRG+1] Add python3.5 to Travis

text: nilearn.check_cache_version is a constant. As such, it should be ALLCAPS. The title says it all (and I think that we shouldn't worry about backward compatibility, given that it is probably not used very much).
